{{Infobox website |name = Culture Inside |logo = CULTUREINSIDE.png |logo_size = 220px |logocaption = |screenshot = |collapsible = |collapsetext = |caption = |url = [http://www.cultureinside.com/ www.CultureInside.com] |slogan = |commercial = No |type = [[social networking site]] |registration = Free |language = English, German, French |content license = |owner = |author = Gila and Dominique Paris |launch date = 2008 |alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 1,856,675 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/cultureinside.com |title= Cultureinside.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> |revenue = |current status = Online |footnotes = }}
'''CultureInside''' is a [[non-profit]]<ref name="pieronymus">{{cite news |url=http://pieronymuskosch.ning.com/profiles/blogs/cultureinside-art-competition |title=CultureInside art competition in Luxembroug |last=Shifreen |first=Frank |date=March 17, 2009 |publisher=Pieronymus Art Network |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref> free [[social networking site]] for the artistic community.<ref name="pieronymus"/> Founded by Gila and Dominique Paris in 2008, it has offices in [[Luxembourg]] and [[New York City]] (United States).<ref name="artslantny">{{cite news |url=http://www.artslant.com/ny/articles/show/5294 |title=Culture Inside/Culture Outside and recent work and influences |last=Shifreen |first=Frank |date=February 28, 2009 |publisher=''ArtSlant'' |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref> They frequently use the network to organize online exhibitions, as well as international exhibits in the United States and [[European Union]].<ref name="linkedin">{{cite news |url=http://www.linkedin.com/companies/cultureinside.com |title=cultureinside.com |last= |first= |year=2010 |publisher=LinkedIn |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref> In April 2009 they received the label ''Creativity and Innovation in the European Year 2009''.<ref name="linkedin"/>
== Founding== The site was founded without external funding or capital a by close group of art and web professionals which included Gila Paris and Dominique Paris.<ref name="pieronymus"/> After a research and beta phase starting in November 2007,<ref name="lulinked">{{cite news |url=http://lu.linkedin.com/in/dominiqueparis |title=Dominique Paris: cultureinside Board member |last=Paris |first=Dominique |year=2010 |publisher=LinkedIn |accessdate=2010-12-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121203234742/http://lu.linkedin.com/in/dominiqueparis |archivedate=2012-12-03 |df= }}</ref> the site was launched in 2008.<ref name="contactus">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/homeen/contact.aspx |title=CULTUREINSIDE: Contact Us |last= |first= |year=2010 |publisher=CultureInside |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref>
==Overview== The site is fully in French, [[German language|German]], and English, with Spanish translations pending as of March 2009.<ref name="pieronymus"/> Its purpose is to serve as an artist's initiative and a free online social network for the international arts community.<ref name="pieronymus"/><ref name="artslantny"/> The site is designed for emerging and mid-career artists, buyers, collectors, galleries, curators, museums, and art schools to interact as a community.<ref name="lulinked"/> Members of the public interested in art are encouraged to join as well.<ref name="pieronymus"/> Different artist e-spaces can be linked together to create friends and group networks.<ref name="lulinked"/>
===Operations===
Gila and Dominique Paris are based in [[Luxembourg]], as is site's main office, which is at Rue Basse, 77 L-7307 Steinsel. In 2008 they began working with close friend and curator [[Frank Shifreen]] to open an office in New York City at 290 Elizabeth Street, #1R.<ref name="pieronymus"/><ref name="lulinked"/><ref name="contactus"/>
In 2010 PRO Services, a professional service for the website's artists that works in connection with an art eCommerce complement, was fully integrated into the platform.<ref name="contactus"/> The service supports an "Art Market Place" where artists can sell original artwork and take orders for "Fine Art Prints" upon demand on museum quality paper.<ref name="linkedin"/> Both the PRO Services and the eCommerce aspects<ref name="contactus"/> are operated by the privately owned company GATE C Sàrl in Luxembourg.<ref name="linkedin"/>
The site's stated goal is to focus on the Grand Region of the [[European Union]], focusing on supporting and integrating cultural efforts in the EU Member States.<ref name="pieronymus"/> Dominique and Gila Paris, founding members, have served as CultureInside board members since November 2007.<ref name="lulinked"/><ref name="stateofcreation"/>
==Exhibitions== Since its inception, CultureInside has used its social platform to organize and curate several exhibits and competitions, with winners premiering their work in high-class galleries and museums through the United States and Europe.<ref name="linkedin"/>
;''ROOTED'' (June 2009) Frank Shifreen and Gila Paris worked through CultureInside to organize ''ROOTED'', an exhibition.<ref name="pieronymus"/><ref name="artistseutopia">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/homeen/e-space.aspx/Artist/EUtopia |title=at the Centre de Rencontre Abbaye de Neumunster, www.cultureinside.com has mounted an exhibition entitled "EUtopia" |last= |first= |date=July 2010 |publisher= |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref><ref name="blurb">{{cite news |url=http://www.blurb.com/bookstore/detail/1253753?ce=blurb_ew |title=ROOTED - The Premiere, by Frank Shifreen and Gila Paris |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Blurb |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> The theme was an "investigation...of the term rooted", with proposals to be submitted in a CultureInside online gallery to be looked over by a curatorial committee.<ref name="rootedpage">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/en/art-exhibition/rooted.aspx |title=ROOTED - The Premiere in Europe |last= |first= |year=2010 |publisher=CULTUREINSIDE |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref> The five winners had their work physically exhibited at the Luxembourg gallery the Galerie Clairefontaine,<ref name="rootedpage"/> while the other 25 finalists had their worked selected for an online show and catalog.<ref name="pieronymus"/> Winners were Brad Carlile of the United States, Adam Martinakis of [[Greece]], Nebojsa Despotovic of [[Serbia]], Myriam Ziade of Luxembourg, and Franca Giovanrosa of Italy.<ref name="carlile">{{cite news |url=http://www.bradcarlile.com/blog/my-art-update/luxembourg-tv-show-brad-carliles-work-at-galerie-clairefontaine/ |title=Luxembourg TV shows Brad Carlile's work at Galerie Clairefontaine |last=Carlile |first=Brad |date=July 1, 2009 |publisher=bradcarlile.com |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref> The show ran from June 25, 2009 to July 25, 2009,<ref name="rootedpage"/><ref name="carlile"/> with the Luxembourg television station RTL.LU KULTUR covering the opening.<ref name="carlile"/>
;''Recession Art Sale Gallery'' (October 2009) In September and October 2009, Shifreen co-produced the ''A Bailout for the Rest of Us: Recession Art Sale'' in Manhattan with Elanit Kayne. It featured thirty artists and thirty out-of-work professional artists. Shifreen hosted the online gallery on www.cultureinside.com.<ref name="cultureinsidenext">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/348/section.aspx/ViewProfile/105 |title=Profile of Frank Shifreen |last= |first= |date= |publisher=CultureInside |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref><ref name="prlog">{{cite news |url=http://www.prlog.org/10316954-bailout-for-the-rest-of-us-recession-art-sale-combines-art-and-commerce.html |title=Bailout for the Rest of Us: Recession Art Sale combines art and commerce |last= |first= |date=August 21, 2009 |publisher=PRlog |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
;''State of Creation'' (June 2010) In June 2010, CultureInside organized the online and physical exhibition ''State of Creation''. Participants must have had a free account on CultureInside, and the proposals of digital art and modern photography were required to be related to the themes of creation, social dynamics, progress and innovation.<ref name="stateofcreation"/><ref name="staeof">{{cite news |url=http://www.photographycompetitions.net/2010/03/state-of-creation/ |title=State of Creation Photo and Digital Art Contest |last= |first= |date=April 18, 2010 |publisher=PhotographyCompetitions.net |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref> The winner was rewarded the "WANE" prize.<ref name="stateofcreation">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/en/art-exhibition/state-of-creation.aspx |title=State of Creation |last= |first= |year=2010 |publisher=CULTUREINSIDE |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref><ref name="staeof"/>
The curatorial committee consisted of Kevin Muhlen, artistic director at the Casino Forum d’exposition in Luxembourg, Serge Basso, artistic director at the Kulturfabrik Esch, Esch-sur-Alzette, Mert Akbal, teacher at the [[University of the Arts (Philadelphia)|University of the Arts]], Saarbrücken, Germany, photographer Jean-Pierre Ruelle, exhibition manager Sara Corti Jayasuriya, Frédérique Gueth of 1,2,3 GO, and Gila Paris.<ref name="stateofcreation"/>
<ref name="staeof"/> The winning artists premiered their work at an exhibition on June 16, 2010 at the Chamber of Commerce in Luxembourg.<ref name="stateofcreation"/><ref name="staeof"/> It was also the tenth anniversary of the group 1,2,3 GO. The following day the exhibition moved to the European Commission in Luxembourg. It then stayed until July 9 at the Conference Center of the European Commission in Luxembourg.<ref name="staeof"/> All the winning work remains part of a permanent online exhibition.<ref name="staeof"/>
;''EUtopia - Artistic Visions of Europe'' (July 2010) On July 28, 2010, Cultureinside.com curated and premiered an art exhibition entitled ''EUtopia - Artistic Visions of Europe'' at the Centre Culturel de Recontre Abbaye de Neumunster, Cloitre<ref name="eutopiacultureinside">{{cite news |url=http://www.cultureinside.com/en/art-exhibition/eutopia.aspx |title=EUtopia |last= |first= |year=2010 |publisher=CULTUREINSIDE |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref> in Luxembourg. The dual theme was centered on the name and the context of "[[poverty]] and [[social exclusion]]" in Europe. CultureInside first organized the show using its base of 3100 online members. 70 pieces of diverse media, including painting, photography, sculpture, digital work, video, and performance, were then chosen by a curatorial committee. The works came from 13 different countries.<ref name="culrtureinside">{{cite news |url=http://cultureinside.com/ |title=EUtopia — Artistic Visions of Europe |last= |first= |date=July 28, 2010 |publisher= |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> The show ran until September 15, and <ref name="eutopiacultureinside"/> a public prize was voted on online.<ref name="bosniart">{{cite news |url=http://bosniart.com/component/content/article/2-konkursi/354-artistic-visions-of-europe-art-competition-for-any-visual-media |title=Cultureinside EUtopia — Artistic visions of Europe |last= |first= |date=May 28, 2010 |publisher=''Bosniart'' |accessdate=2010-12-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708084155/http://bosniart.com/component/content/article/2-konkursi/354-artistic-visions-of-europe-art-competition-for-any-visual-media |archivedate=July 8, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Guy de Muyser, President du Conseil d'Administration du CCRN,<ref name="eutopiacultureinside"/> the organization that runs the Abbaye, as well as the Culture Minister of Luxembourg [[Octavie Modert]], both spoke at the opening ceremony.<ref name="culrtureinside"/>
;''The Crazy Show'' (November 2010) On September 29, 2010, ''The Art Inquirer'' reported on CultureInside's ''The Crazy Show'', a curated exhibition that challenged artists and art groups to submit creative works online that "represent paradoxical ideas that provoke the break of the logical thought." On November 3 the selected works were published on the site, with the CultureInside [[Facebook]] Community choosing the "craziest" work and recipient of a reward.<ref name="theartinquirer">{{cite news |url=http://theartinquirer.blogspot.com/2010/09/cultureinside-crazy-show-2010.html |title=CultureInside: The Crazy Show 2010 |last= |first= |date=September 29, 2010 |publisher=''The Art Inquirer'' |accessdate=2010-12-20}}</ref>
==Awards== *April 2009 — earned label ''Creativity and Innovation European Year 2009'' (Luxembourg)<ref name="linkedin"/><ref name="contactus"/> *September 2009 — Lauréat "1,2,3,GO program" ''Best Business Plan''<ref name="linkedin"/> *April 2010 — ''EUtopia'' received the Label ''2010 European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion'' for its engagement and creative contribution to the EU programme.<ref name="linkedin"/><ref name="lulinked"/>
==CultureOutside== The group is developing a sister website entitled ''Culture Outside'',<ref>[http://cultureoutside.com/ Culture Outside] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110130132935/http://cultureoutside.com/ |date=2011-01-30 }}.</ref> which will exist for the intent of encourage artists and curators to develop and create exhibitions using the site as a catalog. The selected exhibitions will be leasable to galleries and institutions.<ref name="artslantny"/>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.cultureinside.com/}}

revision.comment: added [[Category:Media in the San Francisco Bay Area]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{citation style|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox Magazine | title = Emigre | image_file = | image_caption = | image_size = | company = [[Emigre (type foundry)|Emigre Graphics]] | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | total_circulation = 69 issues | circulation_year = | language = English | category = Graphic Design, Typography | frequency = usually on a quarterly basis | editor = [[Rudy VanderLans]] | issn = 1045-3717 | firstdate = 1984 | finaldate = 2005 | country = United States | website = [http://www.emigre.com] }} '''''Emigre''''' ({{ISSN|1045-3717}}) was a graphic design magazine published by [[Emigre (type foundry)|Emigre Graphics]] between 1984 and 2005; it was first published in 1984 in [[San Francisco, California]], United States. Art-directed by [[Rudy VanderLans]] using fonts designed by his wife, [[Zuzana Licko]], ''Emigre'' was one of the first publications to use [[Apple Macintosh|Macintosh]] computers and had a large influence on graphic designers moving into [[desktop publishing]] (DTP). Its variety of layouts, use of guest designers, and opinionated articles also had an effect on other design publications.
The focus of ''Emigre'' was both redundant and wandering — both positive qualities as a journal produced by a tight and evolving group of designers and writers with Vanderlans at the center. Vanderlans was typically editor, though guest-editors also appeared ([[Gail Swanlund]], Anne Burdick, Andrew Blauvelt) and the work/writing of Zuzana Licko and [[Jeffery Keedy]] reappeared throughout the magazine's history.
The magazine began in 1984 with a focus on the [[émigré]]. The first eight issues were concerned with boundaries, international culture, travel accounts and alienation (as the issues' titles suggest). The first eight issues also incorporated a dynamic aesthetic that caught the attention of designers and led to the next stage in the magazine's evolution.
Beginning with Issue 9 — devoted to the art of [[Vaughan Oliver]] at [[4AD]] — the magazine explored design in itself, devoting issues to [[Cranbrook Educational Community|Cranbrook]], the [[Macintosh]], type design and individual graphic designers. In two issues in 1992 and 1993, the magazine chronicled the work of [[David Carson (graphic designer)|David Carson]] and [[Ray Gun (magazine)|Raygun]].
Increasingly, ''Emigre'' became a platform for essays and writings on design. This aspect of ''Emigre'' came to the forefront with issues in 1994 and the magazine changed its format in 1995 from its oversized layout to a text-friendlier format that debuted with Issue 33. The magazine retained this character through Issue 59 in 2001.
Emigre then took a sharp turn with four re-formatted issues in 2001 and 2002 that included one DVD ("Catfish," an experimental documentary film on the work of designer and performance artist Elliott Earls) and three compact discs (featuring the music of [[Honey Barbara]], [[The Grassy Knoll (band)|The Grassy Knoll]] and Scenic.
In its fifth and final incarnation, the last six issues of ''Emigre'' were co-published by [[Princeton Architectural Press]] as small softcover books. The last issue, The End, was published in 2005.
==Formats== The magazine changed formats several times: it was originally published quarterly in a large format where each page measures 285 mm x 425 mm (slightly shorter than 11" x 17" or US ledger/tabloid size); starting with issue 33, each page was about 8.5" x 11" (US letter size); it changed into a multimedia format (a booklet where each page was 133 mm x 210 mm, plus a [[CD]] or [[DVD]]) starting with issue 60; and finally, starting with issue 64, the magazine became a book format, published semi-annually, where each page measured 133 mm x 210 mm. The issues in the book format were co-published by [[Princeton Architectural Press]].
==See also== *[[Communication Arts]] *[[Eye magazine]] *[[Graphis Inc.]] *[[Print (magazine)]] *[[Ray Gun (magazine)]] *[[Visible Language]]
==References== *''Emigre'' magazine, issues 1–69, 1984–2005. *[http://www.emigre.com/EMagView.php ''Emigre'' magazine’s web page] on Emigre’s official web site *''[[Eye (magazine)|Eye]]'' magazine, Vol. 2, No. 7, 1992, pp. 8–16: ''Rudy Vanderlans'' *''[[Eye (magazine)|Eye]]'' magazine, Vol. 11, No. 43, Spring 2002, pp. 58–64: ''Zuzana Licko'' [http://www.eyemagazine.com/feature.php?id=62&fid=272] *''Merz to Emigre and Beyond: Avant-Garde Magazine Design of the Twentieth Century'', [[Steven Heller (graphic design)|Steven Heller]], Phaidon, 2003.
[[Category:Defunct magazines of the United States]] [[Category:American arts magazines]] [[Category:Communication design]] [[Category:Graphic design]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1984]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 2005]] [[Category:Magazines published in California]] [[Category:Media in the San Francisco Bay Area]]

{{Use British English|date=December 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{unreferenced|date=May 2015}} [[File:Entrance to the Mall Galleries.JPG|thumb|The Mall Galleries building]] The '''Federation of British Artists''' (FBA) consists of nine art societies, and is based at '''Mall Galleries''' in [[London]] where the societies' Annual Exhibitions are held. The societies represent living artists working in the [[United Kingdom]] who create contemporary [[figurative art]]. Mall Galleries aim to ‘promote, inspire and educate audiences about the [[visual arts]].’
==Description==
The FBA has over 500 artist-members, who regularly exhibit their work and also accept open submissions from the public. In addition to the member societies, other societies and individual artists also stage shows at Mall Galleries. Over 100 prizes and awards are administered each year by the societies.
The gallery also has a commissions department and Friends organisation. The galleries' education department runs a Schools Programme, which includes gallery based workshops for Primary and Secondary school students.
Gallery projects include a drawing school and summer courses run by the [[New English Art Club]], as well as The [[Hesketh Hubbard Art Society]], the largest life drawing society in London, who meet to draw from life models.
The FBA is a registered charity, number 200048, and was established in 1961.
In February 2011 the Mall Galleries mounted an exhibition, "Pure Gold: 50 Years of the Federation of British Artists", curated by Anthony J Lester, Hon.RMS, FRBA, FRSA. An illustrated, 100 page catalogue ({{ISBN|978-0-9560219-3-9}}) was published to accompany the show.
==Societies in the FBA==
*[[Royal Institute of Painters in Water Colours]] *[[Royal Society of British Artists]] *[[Royal Society of Marine Artists]] *[[Royal Society of Portrait Painters]] *[[Royal Institute of Oil Painters]] *[[New English Art Club]] *[[The Pastel Society]] *[[Society of Wildlife Artists]] *[[Hesketh Hubbard Art Society]]
==Other exhibiting societies== <!--NOTE TO EDITORS: ALPHABETICAL ORDER--> Societies that have exhibited at Mall Galleries include: *Armed Forces Art Society *East Anglian Group of Marine Artists *[[Free Painters and Sculptors]] *[[The Guild of Aviation Artists]] *The Royal Society of Miniature Painters, Sculptors and Gravers *Society of Equestrian Artists *The [[Society of Women Artists]] *The Society for Art of Imagination *The Wapping Group of Artists
==Prizes== Prizes which are awarded at Mall Galleries include: *[[The Columbia Threadneedle Prize for painting and sculpture]] *The Sunday Times Water Colour competition *ING Discerning Eye
==See also== *[[Ken Howard (artist)|Ken Howard]] *[[William Bowyer (artist)|William Bowyer]] *[[Charles Williams (artist)|Charles Williams]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.mallgalleries.org.uk FBA and Mall Galleries] *[http://www.threadneedleprize.com The Threadneedle Prize for painting and sculpture] *[http://www.discerningeye.org/ ING Discerning Eye Exhibition] *[http://www.thewappinggroupofartists.co.uk The Wapping Group of Artists] *[http://www.thepastelsociety.org.uk The Pastel Society] *[http://www.royalinstituteofpaintersinwatercolours.org The Royal Institute of Painters in Water Colours] *[http://www.therp.co.uk The Royal Society of Portrait Painters]
